member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Converters.EnumFlagMatcher
member.summary: Uses the bitwise AND operator (&) on numeric values to determine whether a value is a match for a target value.
member.remarks: This matcher is useful for testing whether a value includes an enum flag.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Converters.EnumFlagMatcher.MatchOnAnyFlag
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a value must match all flags (the default), or whether a value can match any flag.
member.value: Indicates whether a value must match all flags (the default), or whether a value can match any flag.
member.remarks:
Set to to allow matches against partial flag values. For example, given the flag value ConsoleModifiers.Control | ConsoleModifiers.Shift, the value will match against it.
By default, is set to to allow only exact flag matches. For example, given the flag value ConsoleModifiers.Control | ConsoleModifiers.Shift, the value will not match against it, but the value ConsoleModifiers.Control | ConsoleModifiers.Shift or ConsoleModifiers.Alt | ConsoleModifiers.Control | ConsoleModifiers.Shift would match against it, as these include all of the given flags.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Converters.MatchedValueConverter
member.summary: Converts an input value to a result value by returning the first in the collection that has a matching , or returns if no match can be found.
member.remarks:
Before matching, value conversion is performed to the type of the incoming value, allowing you to specify values and results with simple strings.
Matches are performed against an instance of . By default, an is used, which determines a match using the static method. You can also use the to match values against individual flags.
works the same way as , except that matches are performed against instead, and or is returned.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to use to perform basic conversions.
<!-- Convert a Boolean value to the opposite Visibility value: False: Visibility.Collapsed (Default) True: Visibility.Visible --> <ni:MatchedValueConverter x:Key="BooleanToCollapsedVisibility" DefaultValue="False" DefaultResult="Visible"> <ni:MatchPair Value="True" Result="Collapsed" /> </ni:MatchedValueConverter>
<!-- Convert an interaction mode value to a Boolean value for a specific enum flag: (Default): False EditRange: True --> <ni:EnumFlagMatcher x:Key="EnumFlagMatcher" /> <ni:MatchedValueConverter x:Key="IsRangeEditable" DefaultResult="False" ValueMatcher="{StaticResource EnumFlagMatcher}"> <ni:MatchPair Value="EditRange" Result="True" /> </ni:MatchedValueConverter>

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.IDataMapper.Transform(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Shifts and resizes the data mapper by the specified factors.
member.param: The relative amount to pan the data mapper.
The relative amount to zoom the data mapper.

remarks.para: The pan factor controls the relative position of the edge of the "window" of the mapper closest to the relative coordinate 0. Changing the pan factor has the same effect as sliding this window along the axis. The "width" of the data displayed will not change.
The zoom factor controls the width of the "window" of the mapper in relative coordinates. It cannot be negative or zero.
For example, a pan factor of 0 and a zoom factor of 1 will map from relative coordinate 0.0 to 1.0. A pan factor of 0.1 and zoom factor of 0.3 will map from 0.1 to 0.4.

member.exception:

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.IDataMapperClone.CanUpdate(NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.IDataMapper)
member.summary: Determines whether the data mapper clone can update the specified data mapper with the current state.
member.remarks: For example, if a clone is created on a range data mapper, then the range on the clone is updated, calling will return true since the range data mapper can receive the clone's new range. If a clone is created on a range data mapper, then the range on both the clone and data mapper are updated, calling will return false because the data mapper was modified after the clone was created.
member.param: The parent data mapper used to create this instance, or a related clone.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.IDataMapperClone.Update(NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.IDataMapper,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Updates the specified data mapper with the current state of the data mapper clone, if the target data mapper has not changed state since the clone was created.
member.remarks:
For example, if a clone is created on a range data mapper, then the range on the clone is updated, calling will update the range data mapper with the clone's new range. If a clone is created on a range data mapper, then the range on both the clone and data mapper are updated, calling will fail because the data mapper was modified after the clone was created.
The value of is ignored if is the parent data mapper.
member.param: The parent data mapper used to create this instance, or a related clone.
to apply the current state and pending changes to , or to apply only the pending changes to .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.LinearRangeDataMapper`3.LinearCalculator
member.summary:
Performs linear interpolation on a value in a given range.
For example, given a raw data value starting at Range.Minimum and moving towards Range.Maximum, the corresponding relative value will move linearly from 0.0 to 1.0. If the range is inverted, the relative value will move linearly from 1.0 to 0.0 instead.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.LinearRangeDataMapper`3.LinearOverflowCalculator
member.summary:
Like , performs linear interpolation on a value in a given range, with special consideration to the size limits of the underlying data type.
For example, if TData is , then trying to calculate the interval between (-128) and (127) would require more space than can fit in a .
Instead, we divide the range into two ranges, such as [-128,0) and [0,127], which can be calculated without overflow. Then we use the appropriate calculator based on where the input value falls, adjusting the calculated relative value to match the proportion of the original range that it covers.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.LinearRangeDataMapper`3.LinearOverflowCalculator.SubrangeCalculator
member.summary: Contains information on a subset of the full range covered by the data mapper.

The input string is separated into two parts: the substring that occurs before the first instance of the in the input, and the substring that occurs after the first instance of the in the input.
If occurs more than once in , then will still contain instances of . If is not found in , then will be the empty string.
member.param: The string to separate.

members.member:
Contains standard methods for dependency property validation and coercion.
All methods must follow the appropriate standard callback delegate signature: - bool ValidateValueCallback(object value) - object CoerceValueCallback(DependencyObject d, object baseValue)
A generic type argument can be used to pass the expected type of the value, for use by the method.
ReSharper disable UnusedTypeParameter - matches validation pattern

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.FrameworkExtensions.SetInitialFreezableValue``1(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Windows.DependencyProperty,``0)
member.summary: The purpose of this is to provide the same behavior as 'SetCurrentValue' (allowing direct property assignment for an initial non-frozen default value), while still receiving sub-property change notifications from the Freezable value.
member.remarks: Because 'SetCurrentValue' does not explicitly change the dependency property assignment to 'Local', the Freezable value will never get registered with the parent object (), and so will not raise sub-property changes. Using a binding maintains the lower priority (e.g. allowing future assignments in XAML), and also behaves as 'Local' as far as Freezable inheritance context registration is concerned (though unfortunately this workaround does not function for Freezable collection types, for some reason).
member.param: The object with the property being changed.
The property being changed.
The initial value for the property.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.FrameworkExtensions.SafeSetCurrentValue(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Windows.DependencyProperty,System.Object)
member.summary: The purpose of this is to provide the same behavior 'SetCurrentValue' provides but to execute only when the new value is different than the current one.
member.param: The object with the property being changed.
The property being changed.
The new value for the property.

member.returns: True if the property is set on the owner. False otherwise.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.MathUtility.GetScreenSafeRelativeValue(System.Double)
member.summary: Replaces a very large relative value with a suitable off-screen value that won't end up as infinite and cause exceptions.
member.param: The relative value to clamp.
member.remarks: Because of other mathematical operations that happen when rendering relative values, we can't use a large non-infinite double value like double.MaxValue. Instead, we'll use a value large enough to prevent off-screen values accidentally getting drawn on-screen.
member.returns: A relative value that is not too large for the layout system.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.MathUtility.GetScreenSafeRelativeValue(System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Replaces a very large relative point with a suitable off-screen point that won't end up as infinite and cause exceptions.
member.param: The relative point to clamp.
member.remarks: Because of other mathematical operations that happen when rendering relative values, we can't use a large non-infinite double value like double.MaxValue. Instead, we'll use a value large enough to prevent off-screen values accidentally getting drawn on-screen.
member.returns: A relative point that is not too large for the layout system.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.MathUtility.RoundToSignificantDigits(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Rounds a double value to a given number of significant digits. Note that Math.Round() rounds a double value to a given number of decimal places. For example: RoundToSignificantDigits(12345.6789,3) ==> 12300. Math.Round(12345.6789,3) ==> 12345.679.
member.param: The number to round
The number of significant digits to round it to
The base that determines how significant digits are calculated.
member.returns: The rounded result.

member.param: The operations for the type.
The number to round
The number of significant digits to round it to
The base that determines how significant digits are calculated.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.MathUtility.HalveRangeForOverflow``3(``2,NationalInstruments.Controls.Range{``0},NationalInstruments.Controls.Range{``0}@)
member.summary: Determines whether the given range overflows the bounds of its type.
member.remarks: A bounded signed type can overflow its bounds if the range is large enough. For instance, a range of [Int32.MinValue, Int32.MaxValue] has a span of Int32.MinValue - Int32.MaxValue, which is 2 * Int32.MaxValue + 1.
member.typeparam: The data type.
The helper type.
The descriptor type.
member.param: The data type descriptor.
The initial range to check.
If no overflow, the initial range; otherwise, the upper half of the range (adjusted so that its span does not overflow).
member.returns: Whether the given range overflows the bounds of its type.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.ScopedAccess`1
member.summary: Represents a value that is only to be accessed within a using scope.
member.remarks: This is used primarily for dual queues of items. For instance, one queue might have items waiting to be filled with data, and another queue of items with data waiting to be processed. A can be returned by the class maintaining those queues for a client that fills items with data and then returns them. See for instance the AsynchronousDrawCoordinator" implementation of IBackgroundRenderProcessorCoordinator.WaitForData.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.Tables.Internal.WriteableBitmapExtensions.BlendMode.Alpha

member.summary: Additive blending adds the colors of the source and the destination.

member.summary: Subtractive blending subtracts the source color from the destination.

member.summary: Uses the source color as a mask.

member.summary: Multiplies the source color with the destination color.

member.summary: Ignores the specified Color

member.summary: Copies (blits) the pixels from the WriteableBitmap source to the destination WriteableBitmap (this).

The rectangle that will be copied from the source to the destination.

The blending mode .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.CollectionViewSynchronizer
member.summary: Synchronizes the contents of a source with a target .
member.remarks:
This class can be used to flatten the contents of several separate collections (contained in items in the ), and in effect assign it to a target collection. The can either be assigned directly, or a can be used to generate the .
Synchronization is one-way, from the source to the target . Changes to a target collection that are not performed by the owning will result in undefined behavior.

member.summary: Gets a key used to identify a resource for highlight parts in a control template.
member.value: A for highlight part .
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using to change the highlight part of a control.
<Control.Resources> <SolidColorBrush x:Key="{x:Static niPrimitives:ControlConfiguration.HighlightPartBrushKey}" Color="Yellow" /> </Control.Resources>

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.ControlConfiguration.HighlightPartVisibilityKey
member.summary: Gets a key used to identify a resource for highlight parts in a control template.
member.value: A for highlight part .
member.example:

<Control.Resources> <Visibility x:Key="{x:Static niPrimitives:ControlConfiguration.HighlightPartVisibilityKey}">Collapsed</Visibility> </Control.Resources>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.RangeScale
member.summary: Provides an abstract base class for all scales that use a range.
member.remarks: Scales that use a should derive from this class.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates configuring a RangeScale with a Slider control. It uses a NumericScale, which derives from RangeScale.
<ni:SliderDouble Height="200" Width="200" Range="0,12" Value="6"> <ni:SliderDouble.Scale> <ni:NumericScale ScaleKind="LogarithmBase10"> <ni:NumericScale.MajorDivisions> <ni:RangeLabeledDivisions TickBrush="Black" TickSize="1, 5" /> </ni:NumericScale.MajorDivisions> <ni:NumericScale.MinorDivisions> <ni:RangeDivisions TickBrush="Red" TickSize="1, 2.5" /> </ni:NumericScale.MinorDivisions> </ni:NumericScale> </ni:SliderDouble.Scale> </ni:SliderDouble>

AttachedPropertyComments.name: Stack
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets the identifier of the stack the element belongs in.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: The identifier of the stack the element belongs in. Groups of elements in the same stack are placed on top of each other. Negative values stack from far to near, while non-negative values stack from near to far. The default value is .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.Scale
member.summary: Base class for all scales.
member.remarks: Implementers of are responsible for generating UI elements that display a scale.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates configuring a scale with a Tank control. It uses a NumericScale, which derives from Scale.
<ni:TankDouble Height="130" Width="130" Range="0,20" Value="5"> <ni:TankDouble.Scale> <ni:NumericScale Visibility="Visible" Label="Water Level" LabelOrientation="Natural" LabelVisibility="Visible" BaselineStroke="Blue" BaselineStrokeThickness="1.5" /> </ni:TankDouble.Scale> </ni:TankDouble>

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.ArcSweep.StartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle in degrees where the arc begins.
member.value: A value of type . The default value is 225.
member.remarks: The angle is measured from 3 o'clock as zero degrees and continuing counterclockwise. The value is coerced to be between 0 and 360.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.ArcSweep.SweepAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the measured length of the arc in degrees, measured from the start angle.
member.value: A value of type . The default value is -270.
member.remarks: Positive values go counterclockwise and negative values go clockwise. Value is coerced to be between -360 and 360.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.RadixValueFormatter.ShowRadix
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the numeric value of should be displayed.
member.value:
Calling with set to displays the numeric value of as a subscript after the formatted value.
If is called, or if is called with set to , then is not displayed.
The default value is .
member.example:
The table below shows how the value 123 is displayed by when is :
RadixBaseVisualized Value
(base 10)12310
(base 2)11110112
Quaternary (base 4)13234
(base 8)1738
(base 16)7B16

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.RangeAdjuster.IgnoreDataValueOnRangeChange
member.summary: Gets whether the data value should be preserved on range change.

remarks.para: This value is used to instruct those clients that care about graph data positioning, such as cursors, whether they should try to lock onto data values, even if the range changes. If , then clients will focus on the data value; if , they will maintain their relative position in the graph.

For instance, consider a cursor positioned at 50 in a range of 0,100. If the range is changed to 100,120 and is , the cursor will remain at 50 and move off screen. If is , the cursor will remain centered in the range and its new value will be 110.

member.value: The default value is .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.RangeDivisionsMode.AutoImpl.AutoDivisionsHelper`5.CalculateNiceInterval(`1,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate an interval between minimum and maximum that results in a friendly number of subdivisions (half, quarters, equal thirds, etc.) based on how big the labels for those regions would end up being. "Friendly" in this case is defined by an Internet-found algorithm that tends to make divisions of 2, 5, and 10 and multiples thereof.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation
member.summary: Represents an orientation that is relative to a baseline orientation.
member.remarks: Use implementations of the class to specify how an element should be positioned relative to some baseline.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation.None
member.summary: Gets a value that does not apply orientation to the target.
member.value: A value with no modified orientation behavior.
member.remarks: The object maintains its standard orientation, regardless of its position around the target.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to .
<ni:ScaleLabeledDivisions LabelOrientation="None" />

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation.Natural
member.summary: Gets a value that applies the natural orientation behavior for Cartesian layout.
member.value: A value that applies natural orientation behavior.
member.remarks: When the object is above or below the target, the object is in its standard orientation. On the left side of the target, the object rotates 90 degrees counterclockwise. On the right side of the target, the object rotates 90 degrees clockwise.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to .
<ni:ScaleLabeledDivisions LabelOrientation="Natural" />

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation.Perpendicular
member.summary: Gets a value that applies perpendicular orientation behavior.
member.value: A value that applies perpendicular orientation behavior.
member.remarks: Wherever the object is positioned around the target, a perpendicular orientation is used to keep the object's base tangent to the target at that position.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to .
<ni:ScaleLabeledDivisions LabelOrientation="Perpendicular" />

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation.CreateOffset(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a value that applies offset orientation behavior.
member.remarks: Wherever the object is positioned around the target, a fixed offset from the perpendicular is used. An offset of zero behaves the same as .
member.param: The angle to maintain with respect to the tangent of the orbit around the target.
member.returns: A value that applies an offset with the given angle.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to an offset mode of 45 degrees.
<ni:ScaleLabeledDivisions LabelOrientation="Offset: 45" />

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation.CreateConstant(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a value that applies constant orientation behavior.
member.remarks: Wherever the object is positioned around the target, a fixed constant is used. An offset of zero behaves the same as .
member.param: The angle to maintain.
member.returns: A value that applies the specified constant angle.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to a constant mode of 45 degrees.
<ni:ScaleLabeledDivisions LabelOrientation="Constant: 45" />

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.RelativeOrientation.GetRotationAngle(System.Double)
member.summary: Provides the angle to which the object is oriented.
member.remarks: The standard orientation of an object is how the object appears with no rotation applied.
member.param: The angle required to rotate from the standard orientation to get to the position on the target.
member.returns: The angle to which the object is oriented.

member.summary: Implementation of the None relative orientation.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.ValueFormatterGroup
member.summary: Provides a means for formatting a collection of values.
member.remarks: Use a to format a collection of values. If the property is not empty, the instances will be used for each element of the collection. If there are more elements in the collection than there are value formatters, will be used for the remaining values.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates configuring a ValueFormatterGroup for the value label on a Cursor. It sets the first formatter in the group to display time values, and the default formatter to display numeric values. The two formatters in the group are separated by a semicolon (;).
<ni:Cursor ValuePresenter="Group: yy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss; 0.00" />
You can also use the full element syntax to assign the different ValueFormatterGroup properties explicitly.
<ni:Cursor > <ni:Cursor.ValuePresenter> <ni:ValueFormatterGroup DefaultFormatter="0.00" Separator=" "> <ni:GeneralValueFormatter Format="yy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss" /> </ni:ValueFormatterGroup> </ni:Cursor.ValuePresenter> </ni:Cursor>
